instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.09a
threads.message: Still learning this shit so please bear with me. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is present but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 0v. I'm lost in the schematics lol. Where is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> created and what else should I check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.09a
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP5V_LDO5V</SIGNAL> is present. Does that mean <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.09a
threads.message:
Any history available, liquid sign?
What is exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage, w/ and w/o battery connected?
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes high?

Test the board alone on the desk.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>; use SW9988/89 pads, instead of power button.
Check <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (7 OF 10) LDOs voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.09a
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13.13v (w and w/out batt)
<SIGNAL>PP5V_LDO5V</SIGNAL> - 4.92v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.42v

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 95165, member: 682"]
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>; use SW9988/89 pads, instead of power button
[/QUOTE]
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> sits at 3mv
Short SW9988 or 89 to ground? Or short SW9988 to 89?

Edit:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 95165, member: 682"]
Any history available, liquid sign?
[/QUOTE]
I believe this had liquid damage around the backlight caps on the backside of the board. I had the board labeled as backlight, no image, so I believe it may have turned on at some point. But I don't believe I had another board available to confirm if it was indeed the board or if it was a faulty screen. <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> looks to be missing a leg for pin 3 but I don't believe this would prevent the board from turning on so I was tackling this issue after the ladder.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.09a
threads.message:
"Short SW9988 or 89 to ground? Or short SW9988 to 89?"
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

"Check <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (7 OF 10)"
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL>?
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_VREF</SIGNAL>?

Check also <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>.

Corrosion on the backlight area is the worst scenario.
Leakage from high voltage to data lines, can easy damage CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.09a
threads.message:
Ok so triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> causes a spark and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> goes to 0v then back to 3mv when open again. I didn't understand what you meant by "7 OF 10"

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL> - 3.2v
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_VREF</SIGNAL> - 1.21v
<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> - 0.19v

Also it's probably worth noting when I plug the board into power it draws 0.2a for a second or so then down to 30ma. I believe the90ma in the title was when it was hooked up in the top case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.09a
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> - 0.19v"
PCH can't start the power on sequence then.
Check diode mode to ground there; remove power first!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.09a
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.09a
threads.message: You can remove the filters cap, one by one, and pray isn't <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, or PCH problem.
